comments.author: C(h)ristine
comments.content: Ah!  So THIS is the name of the sandwich I've been eating for years at my in-laws'?  I always thought it was just a family-specific food.  It _is_ delicious, and a happy brunch food.

comments.author: Karina
comments.content: Beautiful! And it sounds incredibly tasty.

comments.author: diva@theSugarBar
comments.content: looks very good. i'm new to jewish food, this is down on my list of to-try

comments.author: Jered Greenwald
comments.content: I didn't see this when I was in Israel and I think my life is lesser for it.  I can't wait to try this out, it looks phenomenal.

comments.author: Cassie
comments.content: Michael, this sandwich looks awesome!  Eggplant is one of my favorite foods and you can bet I'll be giving the vegan version a try.  :)

comments.author: chiffonade
comments.content:
Please delete the post above which begins "thanks a lot guy."  This is NOT me but an internet troll who has been both arrested and jailed for internet harassment.

I apologize for the ramblings of a delusional lunatic.  Your sandwich looks amazing and how the heck did you get that picture to be so perfect???

If you'd like more information about the internet troll, please feel free to e-mail me at chiffonade@hotmail.com.

Till then, keep cooking real (and beautiful) food.  There is no substitute.  (I'll be printing this recipe for sure!!)

Chiffonade,
Clearwater, FL

comments.author: Chef Erik
comments.content: Looks great! Nice plating as well.

comments.author: Sally
comments.content: Drool. Thanks for the gluten-free note! I was attempting to do a "travel" food menu, "traveling" from place to place cheaply by just making Middle Easten, Swedish, Polish, Spanish, etc., food in my own kitchen and pretending I was in those places. Then food prices rose, but I'll be returning to my Middle Eastern meals with this recipe, for sure! Thanks!

comments.author: kathleen
comments.content: On my Google homepage, I just get the titles and this one made me laugh -- my thought was that there was a joke in there somewhere, but clearly I am the only one who thinks an Iraqi Jewish sandwich is amusing.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: See the wikipedia page.

comments.author: alpa
comments.content: OMG, it looks so good and sounds even better! i'm going to make the eggless version this week.  BTW, do you think baking the eggplant would be ok?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: To me, I really like the fried eggplant flavor. I think it would still be good with baked, but definitely not the same. If you are going eggless, maybe add a bit of vegan mayo or something to provide creaminess?

comments.author: Niamh
comments.content: Right, I am making this. Looks divine.

comments.author: Barbara
comments.content: Introduced to this at a stand in Haifa a few months back (still the best after trying at several other places in Haifa and Jerusalem). I prefer over falafel (which was offered as an optional part of the sandwich most places). Delighted to find a recipe--the transliterated spelling was a challenge...

comments.author: RJ Roth
comments.content:
I've been enjoying Iraqi sandwich for over 2 decades in Israel and the US, mostly home-style, and your receipe looks delicious. It is, however, missing 2 touches that will make it even better!  This is popular for Shabbat (Sabbath) lunch. Since traditionally one does not cook on Shabbat, the ingredients are prepared ahead of time. This results in an eggplant marinated in lemon juice, olive oil, garlic and cialntro that is simply divine in itself.

Also, for the same reason,  eggs are typically slow-boiled with onion skins and sometimes  ground coffee, createing a yummy, almost carmel-like result. Even if you do a quick-boiled version, without  "brown eggs" (also known as huevos huminados) it is simply not the same -- please do try it!

comments.author: fmb_356@yahoo.com
comments.content:
Michael,

Great Sabich sandwich recipe. Instead of fried eggplant, I grilled the eggplant which I think brings out it's full complex flavor. The only downside is peeling the eggplant skin post grilling. Also, I used a cilantro/jalapeno hummus. It was delicious. Thank you.

Franco

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Sounds like a winner to me!

comments.author: frantic foodie
comments.content: amba is really not tasty. It is an  aquired taste and the way it tastes in the jar is the way it is supposed to taste. It is also called mango chutney. It comes out of your pores, need I say more.. But sabich, is kick ass

comments.author: ariella
comments.content: Thank You Michael, this looks wonderful. I used to eat amba all the time when I lived in Israel, it is vastly underused condiment in the Israeli-food community here in the states! I love everything about this recipe and am so excited to have found your blog :)

comments.author: Kathy - My Online Meals
comments.content: I would also grill the eggplant I think. It is a lot flavorful as compared to it fried and there'd be lesser grease. Still a great recipe! Thank you Michael. http://myonlinemeals.com

comments.author: Glauke
comments.content:
Thank you thank you thank you! I used to eat this (on Fridays, as a special treat, btw) at the deli around the corner from my old work.

(So, if you ever should visit The Hague, do get a sandwich from Dikke Mik. They are The Best)

comments.author: Dee
comments.content:
hello..i tried this recipe today and it was a total hit ..i love it and definitly making it again
thank you

comments.author: Phil B
comments.content: The best sabich in Tel Aviv was on Frishman street . . . they would put sauteed potatoes in there too, which were always incredible. I've had sabich all over Israel, and I've never had this mango stuff . . . but it sounds good!

comments.author: laurel
comments.content:
This sounds amazing.  Sounds similar to something called Baba Falafel rolled that I get at a local restaurant- similar with some obvious changes.

On the gluten free note ... there are these amazing rice wraps that may be similar enough to pita for those who can't do gluten.  They are called Food for Life Rice Wraps.  I make pizzas out of them all the time.  Not the same, but, it may give you that 'bread' feeling that would put this recipe over the top from just being a salad.

comments.author: jbkassab@yahoo.com
comments.content: My parents are Iraqi Jews and I am proud to say that I grew up with this meal every Saturday morning. I always tell people that I want this to be my last meal. This meal is not only delicious, but just the thought of siblings, friends, grandparents and parents sitting around the table reaching for pita or pouring the Amba or haggling over that last piece of fried eggplant redefines the term comfort food.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks for sharing that very vivid image!

comments.author: Michelle McWilliams
comments.content: I am new to your site and for this whole week I have planned a dinner menu full of your recipes. Tonight I had the Sabich and I love love love it!!! So glad I found this site. Thank You :)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: That's fantastic, Michelle! What else do you have on the menu for the week?

comments.author: Michelle McWilliams
comments.content: We had the Kimchi Fried Rice, Coconut Rice & Beans, and Pasta w/Eggplant. I look forward preparing many more of your recipes. Delish!!

comments.author: Rich
comments.content: If ever in NY, try a hole in the wall Jewish food vendor on 12th Street between University Ave and 5th. My office goes there at least once a week for the Sabich Sandwich. Amazing. Two types of cole slaw, fried eggplant, fried onions boiled egg, pickles, hummus, chilli sauce and white sauce. Amazing. It includes a soda for $5.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Thanks for the tip!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: That's just great that you tried so many! It really makes my day to hear that.

comments.author: Bash Hueglin
comments.content: I am in a hurry to try your recipe.but I am going to try it with the long cooked eggs made with onion skins and a tea bag.  The recipe I am using calls for coffee or tea.  The  coffee doesn't appeal to me so I threw in some tea.  I am making the eggs in a slow cooker, will store them and use them for this great looking sandwich.  Halfway through cooking the eggs you can crack the shells a little and the egg whites will develop some color. Sort of like tie dying. It is similar to a recipe for Chinese tea eggs, which are delicious.

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Yes! My grandma-in-law calls the huevos haminados (in Ladino).

comments.author: Hani
comments.content: Lovely sandwich, Iraqi Jews food is the best

comments.author: Jenine
comments.content: I literally JUST had one of these at the Frishman St stall in Tel Aviv then ran back to my hostel to find a recipe! Saving this one and making it the second I get back to Canada!

comments.author: Joyce
comments.content: Recently, at the David Intercontinental Hotel in Tel Aviv, I had a Sabich sandwich on toasted whole wheat bread.(I'm still dreaming abut it.) I asked the chef how to make it, and she said to grill the sliced eggplant and then put it in the oven for a while to get super creamy. Now I have to buy some tachina, and I'm all set!
